title: Hong Kong Unrest Has High Net Worth Seeking Safer Havens Globally
text:
Text size

Hong Kong’s wealthy, eager to escape political unrest that has grounded flights and prompted violent street clashes with police in recent weeks, are eyeing safe havens outside of China, touring homes in London and Lisbon, and consulting with immigration lawyers.

“It’s not people looking to flee, it’s people looking to make sure there’s a backup plan in place,” said Stephanie Anton, president of Luxury Portfolio International, a company with affiliated real estate brokerages across Asia, Europe and the U.S.

Over two months of protests in the global financial capital—home to 7 million people, including one of the largest concentrations of ultra-wealthy in the world—has rocked daily life for residents, and those with the means are creating contingency plans in case things get worse, according to real estate agents and immigration lawyers. Places that offer residency-for-investment visas—as well as the U.K., in part because of its colonial ties to the city—stand to gain from growing interest in emigration from Hong Kong.

More: Amid Political Changes, Buyers Would Be Wise to Consider Prime Central London

Four high-profile Hong Kong families have retained immigration lawyer Reaz H. Jafri to help them relocate since mid-June, when protests erupted over a now-suspended extradition bill, which would have allowed people charged with certain crimes in semi-autonomous Hong Kong to be sent to mainland China for trial.

“Most of my clients are very, very wealthy, and Hong Kong is a good tax jurisdiction that has maintained its identity from its days as a British colony,” said Mr. Jafri, a New York-based partner with international firm Withers Worldwide. “So for four influential families to decide this in six to eight weeks is quite significant.”

Three of those families intend to acquire European passports, including one who’s purchased a large villa in Italy with plans to apply for residency there, and another who wants to do the same in Switzerland, Mr. Jafri said. He added that the fourth family intends to acquire U.S. residency.

In August, Mr. Jafri was in Hong Kong to meet with clients and was caught in the protests twice, one time at the airport and another when police fired tear gas while he was at a nearby cafe.

In the weeks since then, tension has intensified further. Violence crescendoed a week ago as clashes between police, armed with water cannons and tear gas, and brick-throwing protesters erupted in the first real gunshot fired—a warning from a police officer.

The number of inquiries from Hong Kong flooding Henley & Partners, one of the largest immigration investment law firms in the world, more than doubled in June and July of this year compared to a year ago, said the firm’s CEO, Dr. Juerg Steffen in an email last month.

“We have recently seen a significant spike in interest and inquiries from Hong Kong, as the protests in the city escalate,” Mr. Steffen said. He also attributed the surge in queries to a broader interest in acquiring multiple residencies among the world’s wealthy.

“Our best bet would be that domestic unrest in Hong Kong is only part of the story,” Mr. Steffen said. “High-net-worth individuals all over the world are increasingly looking to new avenues of value and security beyond the traditional sense of wealth: They want a safeguard and an insurance policy for the 21st century.”

For now, many Hong Kong clients eager to pick up homes and residency abroad don’t actually intend to physically relocate, Mr. Steffen said. “For many clients, the appeal of alternative residence or citizenship lies in the fact that it represents a ‘plan B’ should they require it.”

The unrest is fueling demand for so-called “golden visas,” which offer residency in exchange for a large investment, primarily in Europe and to some extent in Malaysia, multiple lawyers and real estate brokers said. Applicants from Hong Kong residents for Malaysia’s residency scheme are up by around 30% compared to those approved last year, Reuters reported last month.

In particular, Portugal’s visa program—which grants residency in exchange for a minimum property investment of €350,000—has seen a marked increase in interest from Hong Kong, said Charles Roberts, a Lisbon-based managing partner at Fine & Country Estate Agents.

Portugal’s investment visa was initially very popular with mainland Chinese but drew little demand from Hong Kong “because they felt they were living in a pretty stable economic, political and religious environment,” Mr. Roberts said. “Since the current troubles started, that has changed.”

Though interest from Hongkongers in Lisbon is very high, he added, converting inquiries into actual sales has been slow.

Luxury Portfolio International agents in Hong Kong have said that some potential emigres may be holding out hope that political tensions will subside, Ms. Anton said. Others also need to sell off property in Hong Kong first in order to free up cash to make investments abroad.

“Many have assets tied to Hong Kong property, which has gotten less liquid—that’s for sure,” Ms. Anton said.

Over the past couple of years, formerly frenzied price growth for houses has cooled in Hong Kong—one of the least affordable real estate markets in the world. Luxury sales prices were flat in the second quarter compared to a year ago, according to a quarterly index from global brokerage Knight Frank. Meanwhile, local agents are reporting a dropoff in viewings as demonstrations disrupt transportation across Hong Kong on the weekends.

This is not the first time residents, fearing the encroachment of Beijing, have looked abroad for peace of mind.

Britain returned Hong Kong to China in 1997 under an agreement for “one state, two systems,” whereby China would allow the city’s capitalist economy to remain until at least 2047. Ahead of the handover, the U.K. made a special status passport—called a BN(O), or British National (Overseas) passport—available to anyone who was a Hong Kong permanent resident before 1997.

In 2015-16, amid an increased encroachment of Beijing in Hong Kong's affairs, foreign visa and passport applications spiked. The U.K. recorded a surge in applications for BN(O) passports, which don’t grant residency but do allow for easy travel to the U.K., Reuters reported at the time.

Now, Hongkongers again are turning to London to make a back-up plan, even as Britain grapples with its own political turmoil over its impending exit from the European Union.

Two London-based real estate agencies and one developer said they’ve seen a spike in activity from wealthy Hong Kong house hunters in prime central London.

"In the past two weeks alone, we have had four serious high-end inquiries from prospective purchasers looking at homes here with many citing the political unrest in Hong Kong as being the primary motive to buy," said Mark Pollack, director of U.K. brokerage Aston Chase, in a mid-August statement.

One such buyer has agreed to buy a “substantial” prime central London apartment, which is intended as a second home but will help “preserve the Hong Kong nationals’ assets and wealth” in case the political situation deteriorates further, the agency said.

London looks particularly attractive to property investors at the moment since home prices in the British capital have fallen roughly 20% from their 2014-15 peak and the pound has broadly weakened against other currencies.

“Overseas buyers are taking advantage of the weak sterling right now, especially those from China and Hong Kong,” said Jonathan Roberts, senior sales manager at Strawberry Star.

Jamie Read, director of London estate agency Tavistock Bow, said the firm has also noted an uptick in Hong Kong buyers who are thinking long-term.

“The change I’ve noticed with buyers I’ve registered recently is that they are less focused on yield or potential for capital growth, and more focused on the idea of London as a safe bet that will hold value for the longer term,” Mr. Read said.

Activists have shown little sign of backing down despite attempts from mainland China to quell the unrest and warnings about the potential economic consequences.

Even if demonstrations do fizzle out, an underlying anxiety over the future of Hong Kong existed before the protests started and will likely remain, said Tony Saich, a professor at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

Mr. Saich, who’s also the director of the university's Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation, said he’s surprised at the duration of the protests and the very wide range of people who’ve participated in them.

“What it shows is how many people in Hong Kong who do not identify with Beijing’s aims and policies, and don’t really see themselves as being Chinese,“ Mr. Saich said. When the protests do die down, “the underlying sentiment of concern and sense that the Hong Kong identity is being eroded will not go away.”

This article originally appeared on Mansion Global .
description: Countries offering visas in exchange for property investment are among the places residents are considering
